audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker expressing pleasure and welcoming the group back to Los Angeles. A cheerful exclamation is heard, followed by the speaker gathering his questions from his notebook, adding that the interview would be difficult because of photos of the group everywhere. The speaker then congratulates the group and refers to their album â€œLove Yourself Tear." Referring back to an earlier interview, he quotes "Love is the key for the integration for all of society" and questions the message behind the new era of "Love Yourself." A second male speaker explains that love is a complex and this time the group wants to focus on the parts of love that people may want to run away from, and that if someone is untrue to themselves love won't last. He adds that love can be between two people but also between a person and themself.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker complimenting something as "beautiful." He then shifts the topic to discussing pressure, specifically regarding a song being the first off an album, inquiring if it brought pressure to the artist. In response, a male says "Of course." He then mentions that individuality can be very difficult and hard. This transitions to another male mentioning a "weird feeling to not have the group around you" to which another male affirms with "Yeah." Then someone says in Korean that they have never seen their friend dance so hard. Then there are sounds of clapping followed by a male's voice, saying "He did well." There is another male voice remarking that someone did an "amazing job" and refers to him as "dreamy." Finally, another male asks about the meanings of songs in the album.

The audio clip begins with a male interviewer speaking in a conversational tone, questioning whether internationally successful groups have a "moral obligation" to create "social conscious songs," suggesting it should be a "necessity" with their level of fame. A male responds in Korean, mentioning "successful singer" and stating that "a person of influence speaking in a good direction gives good energy." He continues in Korean, expressing his desire for the world to be positive and peaceful. The interviewer follows up with "That's beautiful, I love that." The clip ends with the interviewer announcing that "the BABY AMA's are coming out."

The clip begins with upbeat, excited speech from both a male interviewer and a male band member about performing a new song and what fans can expect, including new visuals, dances, makeup, glasses, and hairstyles. The interviewer mentions that the band has changed a lot since 2013. The band members then joke about one of them having changed, claiming he's working out and bigger now. They continue to compliment each other's hair and appearance in a cheerful manner. The clip ends with a declaration of change. Throughout the interview, a lively pop music song plays softly in the background.

The audio begins with a conversational tone as a male speaker asks what advice they would give to themselves if they could go back to 2013, and speculates that they would not have known things would turn out the way they have. Multiple male speakers then respond, one saying "Please study English," a second says, "your hope is big energy, cheer up," a third says, "don't name yourself rap monster, you're a human," and another says, "I'm proud of you." Another person is heard saying, "You nice" and "keep going." Another voice then says, "Dance practice hard, more" and ends by saying "please study English."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, in a conversational tone, referencing charity work and a past discussion about UNICEF and giving back. He notes that the fans of the speaker have been inspired to donate to charities. The male speaker then asks why it's important to give back. A different male speaker answers, in a more serious tone, that he feels like they get more love than they deserve and therefore it's important to give back, especially to people who get so much love, since love is a resource that can be given back again and again. He ends by stating how important it is to give back.

The audio clip begins with speech, where a male speaker recalls a past conversation with Suga from BTS about their aspirations. He then transitions to asking about BTS's next goal. Suga answers, saying "Grammy." In the background, there's enthusiastic chatter and laughter. This is followed by the first speaker saying, "You say that now, but watch. This time next year we'll be like, so, the Grammy's." A second, more serious male voice then interjects, stating, "Grammy's like a whole another world." The audio concludes with the sound of chatter.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating "Okay, I think, I think he... I think he said it first time", followed by another male who agrees and laughs. After a short pause, a male presenter speaks, focusing on acknowledging the "Army" for all their different reasons for love, and then poses the question of what the "BTS" would want to be remembered for in 20 years. Next, a non-English speaker, likely one of the BTS members, responds with an emotional and passionate statement. The presenter responds appreciatively and congratulates them on their album and "Hope World", followed by enthusiastic cheering. There is a transition back to the presenter's voice as he thanks them. One of the male members compliments the presenter, while a male speaker speaks some gibberish. The scene ends with sound of someone smelling something and saying that the smell is amazing, then suddenly an electrical zap sound. The clip concludes with two different male voices speaking about hair and saying that they are good.
